awd_titl_txt: Cybermanufacturing: Cloud-Based Incubation Ecosystem for EWOD Digital Microfluidics
awd_abstract_narration:
Electrowetting-on-dielectric (EWOD) is a mechanism that allows physical handling of liquids with only electrical signals, such as digitizing a liquid into tiny droplets and manipulating them on a chip, thus enabling "digital microfluidics." As an elegantly simple platform free of pumps or valves, EWOD digital microfluidics has been attracting high research interest in the past 15 years and has recently been transitioned to a few commercial products in displays and biochemistry. However, the number of labs utilizing the technology is still small, likely due to the difficulty in translating design intent to manufactured devices. The project will perform fundamental research to enable a cloud-based EWOD manufacturing system to perform that translation. The resulting cybermanufacturing ecosystem will be accessible to a wide range of users, allowing researchers, entrepreneurs, students, and hobbyists alike to focus on their own ideas and applications without having to master the subtleties of EWOD engineering and manufacturing. This may be thought of as an "operating system" for EWOD microfluidics, similar to the computer operating systems that enabled people with no computer hardware background to use personal computers. This cybermanufacturing system is envisioned to have a similar impact on the field of EWOD digital microfluidics. The project includes incorporation of research results in coursework, outreach to and involvement of undergraduate and high school students, and collaborations with an established chip foundry and a distinguished biochemist. 

The research will incorporate knowledge from EWOD research in a framework of cloud-based design and manufacturing. If manufacturing is transparent, people of a wide range of disciplines and levels can take advantage of EWOD digital microfluidics. A design/manufacturability engine will allow users to express their specific intention in a step-by-step EWOD-compatible design protocol, which then will be converted to a verified manufacturable EWOD chip layout. When an order is placed, the design file will be sent to a chip fabrication foundry. The user may also order an EWOD control module and ancillary modules (e.g., programmed heating, magnetic beads), advised by the design system and community experience. A gateway will be made available through online graphical user interface that allows the user to operate multiple modules and systems remotely, greatly expanding the capability and promoting collaborations. The system architecture will ensure bottom-up, organic growth of users and providers as well as the knowledge in design, manufacturing, and application of EWOD digital microfluidics.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit:

Electrowetting-on-dielectric (EWOD) digital microfluidics (DMF) is a platform technology that enables manipulation of individual droplets with only electrical signals. Despite immense interest and remarkable success in academic research, this technology has not seen the wide adoption once anticipated, and the commercialization has been painfully slow. Identifying that the manufacturing barrier is the main culprit that discourages non-engineering groups from adopting the EWOD DMF technology, a UCLA team performed interdisciplinary research to investigate and design a cloud-based platform for EWOD chip design and manufacturing aimed to serve the masses. The cybermanufacturing service is to cultivate an ecosystem where a wide range of users (e.g., researchers, entrepreneurs, students, hobbyists) can focus on their own ideas and applications without worrying about the engineering and manufacturing side of EWOD technology.

The UCLA team created a framework of cybermanufacturing ecosystem for EWOD digital microfluidics, which consists of four major components: (i) portal website, (ii) cloud-based design and manufacturing platform, (iii) EWOD control system and ancillaries, and (iv) online community. As the gateway between the users and the cybermanufacturing platform, a portal website (named “eDroplets”) has been built on a cloud server, through which users can access all the tools and services. A cloud-based EWOD chip design tool has been written to assist single-electrode-layer EWOD chip design. The cloud-based EWOD chip manufacturing platform has been prototyped to accommodate the workflow of fabrication service for three types of EWOD chips: glass-based, PCB-based, and glass-based chips. Standard fabrication process for glass-based EWOD chip was developed, and the design rules have been incorporated into the EWOD CAD. A general PCB-based EWOD chip, designed for users to quickly validate their ideas on before designing their own, has also been developed and made available. An EWOD control system compatible with various chip types has been developed and made available. A web-based operating software has been developed and deployed on a cloud server for users to operate EWOD chips using the control system. An EWOD online community has been prototyped for users to share knowledge and experiences. The UCLA team also performed a beta test by providing the EWOD CAD, EWOD control systems, and operating software to 6 research labs from 4 countries. The structured framework of the EWOD cybermanufacturing ecosystem has opened the door for a standardized design and manufacturing platform for DMF, which is anticipated to not only allow anyone from anywhere to utilize DMF with an affordable cost but also empower foundries to achieve breakthroughs in DMF for future manufacturing.

Broader Impacts:

The framework of cybermanufacturing ecosystem will greatly broaden the user base of the EWOD DMF. Designed for users of all levels and different goals regardless of their expertise, the ecosystem is expected to serve the masses - from hobbyists and high school students to academic and industrial researchers. By removing the manufacturing barrier, a wide range of users will be empowered to create more innovative applications in biology and chemistry. On the flip side, the cybermanufacturing system with a large user basis is expected to provide a platform and incentive the industry (CAD companies, instrument manufacturers, and chip foundries) to advance the EWOD DMF technologies.

Through the project, 3 graduate students, 21 undergraduate students, and 3 high school students - with about half of them being underrepresented minorities - have gained valuable research experience. The research results have been integrated into undergraduate and graduate courses at UCLA and have enriched its curricula. The project outcome has been widely disseminated through scientific publications, conference presentations, invited seminars, and lab websites, drawing interests and inspiring more ideas.


Last Modified: 06/24/2023
Modified by: Chang-Jin Kim
